including a Rails to Trails link - at Route 322 and Glenwood Avenue, and a new signal at Route 50 and Chapel Road that will be activated by the end of November.In 2024, SHA will begin construction on two additional projects: reconstructing the signal at Route 50 and Route 309 and upgrading the flashing signal at Route 331 and Black Dog Alley to a full signal.Two local trail projects are also receiving federal and state grant funding, Pines said.$48,000 will go toward the final design of a 1.25-mile extension of the St. Michaels Nature and Bike Trail, and $30,000 will go toward the study and preliminary design of a rail trail connecting parks in Oxford.Turning to public transit, nearly $1.1 million in operating and capital grants are being allocated to support Delmarva Community Transit.$225,000 of this will fund preventative maintenance and two new small buses, said Travis Johnston, the Maryland Transit Administration's local transit support director.Delmarva Community Services will also receive $123,000 to install a propane filling station for future propane-powered vehicles, enabling DCS to transition to a low-emission fleet.Additionally, $24,000 in highway safety grants were awarded to the Talbot County Sheriff's Office and the Easton Police Department.Turning to the skies, the Easton Airport's runway improvement program is receiving $525,000 from the Maryland Aviation Administration to support the initial phase of construction.THINKING DOWN THE ROADLocal officials also weighed in on a number of priorities and problem areas they hope the transportation agency will address in the future.Discussions on traffic surrounding the proposed new regional medical center site off of Route 50 were top priorities for state legislators, the county and the Town of Easton.

content: ## Veterans and civic observances

source_sentence: Talbot County to light up green for veterans October 25, 2023 | Star Democrat, The (Easton, MD) Author/Byline: Contributed | Page: 4 | Section: News 390 Words Read News Document In advance of the upcoming Veterans Day holiday, the Town of Easton plans to illuminate town and county buildings green from Nov. 6 through 12 - part of Operation Green Light for Veterans.The nationwide initiative, led by the National Association of Counties, raises awareness around the unique challenges faced by many veterans and the resources available at the county, state and federal levels to assist veterans and their families.The Town of Easton will be working together with the Talbot County Government on this project, with plans to light up Town and County buildings along with encouraging local businesses and residents to join in support of veterans.Now in its second year, Operation Green Light is spearheaded by NACo and the National Association of County Veterans Service Officers, building upon successful efforts by the New York State Association of Counties and the NYS County Veteran Service Officers' Association in 2021.In 2022, over 300 towns and counties participated in Operation Green Light."It's a great way to remind our community of all that our veterans have done for our country over the years," said Easton Mayor Megan Cook."In addition to the green lights on our buildings, we also want to shine a light on the employees in our organization who have served, and in some cases continue to serve our country.
source_title: Talbot County to light up green for veterans
